turn.text: Well, I think there are a lot of vices inherent in sitting --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Which is it here?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: Well, here it’s learning defense strategy, that would be when Weatherford already knew the incriminating evidence, but that could be involved or people might be concerned about evidence of other crimes or --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, doesn’t make a little bit of a difference what you’re claiming as to whether the violation occurs at the trial or when you’re sitting down on a meeting?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: Well, I think, Your Honor, it’s getting around again to the question of res judicata and collateral estoppel.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: No, not at all.
Not at all.
I’m just wondering what the constitutional violation is and when it occurs.

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: Well, there are different kinds of harm that could result the harm here which is twofold.
It was that the defense strategy was captured and it could’ve been that it was relate to at least a member of the prosecution.
We did not prove that that defense strategy had actually been related to the prosecution.
But it’s clear that knowledge of an opponent’s tactics give a person quite an advantage on an adversary situation.
That’s one of the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But what about the time he was sitting in, they were also planning another crime?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: I think that would be different, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You mean, that would be admissible?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: Well,--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, would there be a constitutional violation at that time?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: I don’t know that the right to plan a crime is constitutionally protected in the sense that the right to plan a defense is constitutionally protected.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You will suggest there wasn’t any violation there of a third party, a government agent sitting in on those kinds of conversations?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: Well, it shows roughly now the situation that was involved in the Hoffa case.
The Court --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I take it under your position there would’ve been a 1983 violation in the Hoffa case?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: Well, of course that involve the United States Government there but the Court didn’t --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But it would be a constitutional violation, you’d say?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: The Court didn’t rule.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The Sixth Amendment right to counsel?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: Had the State been the prosecuting party that may well have been that Mr. Hoffa could have an action on the 1983 for what happened --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I know but the Federal Government is and that if that’s a violation of a Sixth Amendment, there might be a Bivens type of action?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: We certainly don't rule about that possibility, Your Honor.
Perhaps, there could have been.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, your theory seems to reach that --

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- in the Hoffa case that at the time the agent was sitting in on conversations between lawyer and client, there was a violation?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: Right, sir.

If there would be a violation for the intrusion that occurred at the case at which it occurred rather than a case or prosecution, which would grow out of the criminal activity, was might have been discussed.
I think Hoffa involves that the duality of situation.

It clearly suggests that had Hoffa been convicted that is test to the trial that he would’ve had grounds to set aside that conviction on the grounds of intrusion and I assume that he would also have a 1983 action.

The Solicitor General has raised an issue involving the general use of informers and has suggested that if the opinion of the Court of Appeals is to be affirmed in this case then it would provide a so-called “fail safe method” for detecting informants.
We responded to that in our brief but let me simply add to that or direct the Court’s attention to a testimony by Strom.
He indicated that the ruling of the Fourth Circuit or he testified that the present practice in South Carolina was not to allow undercover agents to participate in defense strategy sessions.

He claimed that it happened in this case because he was ignorant of it but he was quite pointed in his testimony that he simply would not permit one of his agents to participate in defense consultations and he didn’t qualify his remark in the way that such instructions are qualified apparently which are given to the FBI.
He stated that informer participation in defense strategy sessions it wouldn’t be ethical, it wouldn’t be legal.
So that it does not appear that the ruling of the Fourth Circuit varies in any way what the present practice of the stated practice is in South Carolina.

I think this fail safe argument also overlooks this fact that a person would decline an invitation to participate in defense planning sessions for a number of reasons and some of them will have nothing to do with the fact that that person was an agent.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. McDonald, let me just interrupt once more, if I may.

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What is the authority or the closest authority for the proposition that there’s some kind of protection, either constitution or otherwise for a “defense strategy session” other than a session which only the attorney and the client were present.
I mean, we don’t have normal privilege situation but where is the source for this notion of a broad grouping that’s also protected?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: I think there are number of cases, Your Honor which established that proposition.

Hoffa for example assumed that Caldwell and Coplon had been correctly decided and in Coplon, the Court there articulated a right of a defendant to have an un-surveilled defense planning relationship with an attorney.
I think that --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Is it when the third person present between the defendant and the attorney as well?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: Well, of course, those cases involve electronic surveillance, but the Court --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So, those were the intrusions on the privacy of the attorney and the client.
I was just talking about intrusions on the non-privacy of the attorney, the client and the third party.
Are there any such cases?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: I’m not certain I understand the question, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, it’s easy to understand what you’re talking about when you got an attorney and a client in a normally privileged situation and there’s an intrusion on that relationship.
I’m asking you what cases are that had involved a three-party situation; an attorney, a client, and a third party and then someone else intrudes.
What is the source of your notion that that relationship is protected?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: Well, I think that it would be protected by the notion that the right to confer with an attorney includes the notion to prepare a defense and preparation of defense it seems to me --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, I’m not asking about the theory of the other cases that established this general notion that’s what I’m trying to --

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: Well, there are cases, Your Honor we cited in our brief involving the attorney-client privilege, which say that communications made between joint defendants and attorneys is protected by the attorney-client privilege and I should think that the scope of the protection forwarded by the Sixth Amendment would not be less than that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Let me put it to you this way.
Suppose there were two people sitting in on a defense at these same meetings.

One was the government agent and the other one was not a government agent at the time and never was a government agent except that the government heard that he was sitting in and he agreed to testify and he offered his testimony at the trial?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: Well, the Sixth Amendment violation would not exist in that circumstance.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Alright and then you don’t think that the information -- that the testimony of that non-agent would be excludable?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: If he acted without informant whatsoever, I’d (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You can postulate all you want, there is no connection of the Government.

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, then they call the agent at the same trial?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: I think that one of the things --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: To testify the identical things?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: The Sixth Amendment does apply against the Government I think is the answer to that and the Court also --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I know but the question is, was it a confidential meeting or wasn’t it?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: Well, I think it’s --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Or was it something that they could expect to be private or not?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: Well, of course --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Let’s say, you had two extra people in the meeting besides the client and lawyer?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: The Court might conclude that there had been a deliberate waiver, or that there was no attorney-client meeting to intrude, or that there had been no intrusion And that was a meeting that was open to the public or that is going to complete publication of the strategy and those considerations might call for different result than the one we think is appropriate here where there was prosecutorial misconduct.
There was deliberate intrusion as the Fourth Circuit found and there was also substantial interference with the right to prepare for the trial.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Suppose that Weatherford had never attended any meeting at which Bursey’s attorney was present, and then nevertheless testified as he did here?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: I think the Court --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Would you be here?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: Well, we might not be here, Your Honor.
I think the Court would have to look at a number of factors if there was no intrusion --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We wouldn’t have to look at any of them now, would we?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: Well, there would be no intrusion under those circumstances --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But you would’ve (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: We would’ve been --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You would’ve been no less surprised, would you?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: No.
I think we would’ve been much less surprise because what the Government did here is that it deliberately ruled out the very case which it presented.
Had they not done that, had Weatherford not deliberately said that he was not going to be there when he knew there was a possibility that he could be there.

Had he not done that then the defense could not have ruled out the possibility of this testimony but because of the very specific misrepresentations which you made, the very case that was presented was the one case which had been completely rule out.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That being the eyewitness testimony of the fugitive presumed accomplice?

turn.speaker: laughlin_mcdonald
turn.label: Mr. Laughlin McDonald
turn.text: The testimony of Weatherford, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We’ll resume there at 1 o’clock.
